body: I think you don't have to mention it, from a legal point of view, but I think its nice.

This is also important for strings that may have leading spaces and want to preserve those.
Yeah, I'm saying in a comment that it's adapted from Spark.

The code looks very good! 

I think it should include the Java8 documentation, though.
Since the exception message explicitly refers to the documentation for further information, the docs should be part of the pull request.

The documentation should also explain what users have to do to turn a maven project generated from our quickstarts into a Java8-Eclipse JDK project ;)
We could also add another quickstart/maven archetype, but that would mean a new maven module in our build..

I would suggest a new section "Java 8 Lambda Expressions" for the "Java API Programming Guide" which explains how to use lambdas (with examples) and configure maven. I think it makes sense to rename the whole "flink-java8-tests" subproject to "flink-java8" and put some example in there.

I would actually vote to make this a top-level section, like
- Java API
  - Java 8
  - Transformations
- Scala API
Good fix and good to merge
I'll merge.

I think adding a JIRA ticket for the issue would be great.

Looks good, this is almost ready to merge. Two minor comments:
- The `configure()` method of the output format is invoked also on the master. The open Method would therefor be the better place for the RMI initialization, in my opinion, it would help efficiency.
- Also, a naming convention: We don't start interfaces with `I`. For the sake of a homogeneous code style, I would ask you to follow a similar style.

We have a major change of the JobManager pending (that also affect the web frontend a bit): #122 

I'll have a look how this works together with the changed code. It should not be a serious issue.

I think, there is already a ticket for this issue (FLINK-98).
Please check and add a comment if you think something is missing.
Good to merge
Thanks Stephan. Integrated the changes. We put the RMI initialization into the constructor, is this fine too?
Thanks! Will merge this to master today.
The issue still that it RMI should only be initialized on the workers. If you put the code in the constructor or "configure()" it will be initialized on the client-or master-side as well.

What would you say about merging this now?

Thanks Henry! Looks good to me. The build failures on travis are related to missing artifacts which travis could not download from maven central. I assume that this is a server side issue. I'll merge the PR.

When using a rebalance operation, the plan visualiser does not actually say "rebalance". Can someone who knows the optimiser whether this is an actual bug. This also existed before I did this rewrite.

The DOP of the partition operator needs to be explicitly set to the DOP of the receiving task. Otherwise, the data is shuffled again.
I'm pretty sure this behavior is never wanted and think it opens a potential trap. Also multiple successors with different DOPs might cause problems.
These were exactly the cases, I tried to avoid with my implementation (+ repartitioning where it does not make any sense).

The way it is done in this PR, makes things more explicit and controlable for the user. A user can do more stuff but also a lot of very stupid things.
I would prefer the safer alternative, but won't veto if others find this is a better solution.

However, if we go with the PR, I vote to make the risk of this operator mcuh more clear in the JavaDocs and the documentation.
We could also include the DOP as an additional parameter to rebalance() and partitionByHash() and deactivate the setParallelism() to make clear that the DOP is very important for this operator (-1 could be used for the default parallelsim).

I think this variant is a lot simpler and keeps the API clean. Calling partitioning is something that a user should use, when he wants explicit control, and I think it is okay if that leads to situations where the partitioning turns out redundant (we could also fix this later with optimizer rules, but we cannot fix the API once public).

When calling explicit partitioning before a join, the optimizer will reuse the partitioning. When calling it before reduce, only the combiner will be dropped.

Regarding parallelism: Calling rebalancing when the DOP changes is redundant, because the DOP change will cause a rebalance by itself, but it does not hurt. Calling partition() and then change the DOP voids the partitioning, that is true. I would accept that for now and rather throw an error now (e.g. in the optimizer "partition operator followed by DOP change", and later fix it with an optimizer rule or so)
The reasoning is that internals are so much easier to change than APIs.

Well, the API is pretty much the same in both variants. The only difference is that more operations may follow a partition operator and that partition results in a partition operator and not a partitioned data set.

Anyway, as I said, if this solution is considered to be better, go for it...

Any comments on the suggested API change of rebalance() and partitionByHash()?
Thx for merging this, Till :)
In the proposed variant, we have no "PartitionedDataSet" any more. I think that makes it easier. The underlying PartitionOperatorBase is the same.

Perfect, thank you!
Good javadocs are very important, in particular the user-facing public methods.

I was thinking about adding something like a "quality assurance" bot to our github pull requests. One task of this bot could be a check that a pull request is not adding more javadoc errors. Hadoop has something similar for the JIRA patches: https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=hadoopqa

How do you ensure that `flink-dist` has been build before `flink-yarn-tests`?
I think its a bit weird that `flink-yarn-tests` is a top-level maven module and `flink-yarn` is under addons.
The reason why I told you that you'll probably need another maven module was different. When I looked into this, i wanted to execute the maven assembly plugin in a pre-test-phase of maven.
Therefore, I could simply copy the uberjar-assembly descriptor from "flink-dist" or add a third project "flink-assembly-descriptors" where the two projects can pull the assembly descriptor from.
But the whole thing did not really work out.
I'll test your changes once my POJO pull request is out and we are doing pre-release tests.

Good to merge. All operator tests are working.

+1
Manually merged.

Thanks for the feedback.

Afaik maven sorts the modules according to their dependencies and to their position in the pom.xml of the flink-parent. In the flink-parent, the yarn-tests module is the last one. Also, the yarn tests are executed during the integration-test phase which occurs after the packaging phase. Thatswhy the flink-dist uberjar should be already build when the yarn integration tests are executed.
Manually merged in 65bf092da77ca0d416a3abbcac21b641cf038101
Nice :-) I am trying it out now...
I would suggest to put the type extractor tests that test pojo detection into a dedicated class. The type extractor test class is overflowing...

The TupeSerializer and the TupleComparators have pretty massive stand-alone tests. I could not find something similar for the PojoSerializer.

Check out the `AbstractGenericTypeSerializerTest`, on which the AvroSerializer and the KryoSerializer build their tests. Adding a subclass of that test for the POJO serializer should increase test coverage quite a bit with very few lines of code.

The error message _"Type GenericType<test.PoJoTestProgram.MyType> is not a composite type. Key expressions are not supported."_ is not very helpful, IMHO.

How about writing something like `Key expressions are only supported on POJO types. A type is considered a POJO if all its fields are public, or have bother getters and setters defined`. That would immediately tell the user where to look for the error, or how to alter his types.

Looks good all in all. The comments should all be rather easy to address.
After that, +1 for merging.

Thank you for the thorough review. I'll address the issues.

Regarding the serializer test, there is the `PojoSerializerTest extends SerializerTestBase<PojoSerializerTest.TestUserClass>`. It is doing 12 tests (copy, instantiation, etc).
I'll look into the Tuple Serializer tests and see what I can do for the PojoSerializer. But there are definitively tests for the comparator missing.

The problem with this issue is, that you don't know what is happening inside of the {{jobCommit()}} method.
For Hadoop FileOutputFormats it only removes the temp directory but other formats might have important logic in there. So removing that call is not a good solution.

I am currently working on another solution that adds a hook to the JobManager which is called after all output tasks finished. Will open a PR soon.
And sorry that I forgot to assign the issue to myself :-/
